text:
MICHAEL SMERCONISH: You
went through, what was it?

330 cases of terror that had
been prosecuted in the United
States since September 11.
Who are the 330?

PETER BERGEN: Well, they're
overwhelmingly Americans.

And in fact, the sample size,
Michael, since we last spoke,

has grown to I think something
like 375 cases since 9/11.

And four out of
five of these cases

are American citizens
or legal residents.

Very few of them are
refugees-- about a dozen.

And none of those cases involve
acts of lethal terrorism
or attempted lethal terrorism.

So this banning of refugees
is kind of a red herring.

And by the way, we've
accepted 10,000--

15,000 Syrian refugees,
as you know, Michael.

None of them have
been alleged to have

been involved in any form
of terrorist activity.

They have to go through a very
rigorous screening already.

So it's one of those, sort
of like, it sounds good,

but as a practical
matter, it's not

going to make any difference
to the terrorism issue, which

is overwhelmingly a
domestic terrorism--
a United States problem.

Because 9/11, of
course, was carried out

by 19 foreign-born
Arab terrorists,

I think we tend to conceive of
this as a problem that comes

from outside, when
in fact it's really

a problem that is internal to
the United States right now.

MICHAEL SMERCONISH:
And the chilling

observation I remember
from reading your book
is that they are leading--

those who are here and
are causing terrorism--

they are leading
seemingly normal lives.
You know, they're married.
They have jobs.
They're not necessarily loners.
PETER BERGEN: Right.

I mean, we tend to think of
people engaged in terrorism

as perhaps poor, and very young,
and guys who are without family
responsibilities.

But the kind of general picture
you see from these cases is,

you tend to be about a third are
married, a third have children.

You know, reasonably
well-educated.

And so they're
ordinary Americans.

And many of the most
lethal terrorist attacks

have been carried out
by American citizens
who were born in this country.

Think of Omar Mateen,
who killed 49 people
in Orlando at the nightclub.
He was born in New York City.

Think of Major Nidal Hassan, who
killed 13 at Fort Hood, Texas.

He was born in
Arlington, Virginia.
And the list goes on.

You know, one thing that I
thought was sort of surprising,

Michael, the seven other
Muslim countries where there's

been a kind of a temporary
ban on any immigration
for about six months--

one country that wasn't
on that list is Pakistan.

Which I was sort
of surprised by,

because there is a
case, which I think

is a reasonable
one for supporters

of Trump's actions to point to,
which is the woman in the San--

the wife in the San Bernardino
case where the 14 people were
killed in December of 2015.

She actually was a
relatively recent migrant

from Pakistan who came
to the United States
on her fiancee visa.

But Pakistan strangely
wasn't on this list.

There is a number
of Muslim countries.
So it's sort of puzzling.

Obviously it was a
campaign promise,

but it's one of
those things that

sounds like it makes sense,
but it doesn't really
when you look at the facts.
